body: r? @alexcrichton

@alexcrichton yeah I was just running a `make check` pass and I think I am seeing errors similar to the ones that I had thought were rustdoc issues.  Not sure yet.  I am doing another clean `make check` against master first to see if I can track this down.

p.s. thanks for the suggested patches, I will see if they help things.

---

update: I was wrong on two counts; The failures I mentioned above we encountered using `make check-stage2` (not `make check`) and they were not rustdoc failures.
Could you paste the errors you've been seeing? I'm curious myself!

@alexcrichton I misspoke earlier; it was actually compilation-fail failures running `make check-stage2`.  it is possible that `make check` would have worked fine atop my patch queue.  But in any case, I still want to try to apply your suggested patch and see if it helps me with my rustdoc issues, especially if it means that I misfiled #13983

https://gist.github.com/pnkfelix/80e43dea9974aea58de6

and actually, I think the failures I listed above occur on the master branch as well.

That is, this may just be a general problem we have with running `make check-stageN` for any `N`, but no one notices it even for stage2 because everyone just does `make check` instead of `make check-stage2` ?

it looks to me like the right solution here is to factor out the compile-fail tests that rely on syntax extensions in a separate crate into a separate directory, analogous to our run-pass-fulldeps.

I will work on that and file separate PR for it.
(closing this until I get `make check-stage2` working on its own...)
filed PR #14014 for the `make check-stage2` fix.
(reopening since huon gave thumbs up on #14014.)

@alexcrichton so it seems like the `rustdoc` problem is (once again) something where the compiler chooses one library it finds for `libnative` and it does not match the choice made by the dynamic searching when we run the executable itself.

Of particular interest: it seems like the override of the `DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH` is causing the problem.  If we omit that, then things _seem_ to work, though I am not yet sure exactly why.

Here is an example of what I am seeing:
https://gist.github.com/pnkfelix/9c2c186b420645b852b3

Problems like this were what led me to just disable rustdoc entirely for stage1 rather than attempt to decipher where I needed to adjust the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` in the `make -> run rustdoc -> run compiled code block` chain...
I discussed this with @pnkfelix on IRC. We think we have a fix for rustdoc stage1 tests, but we'll land this in the meantime while the solution cooks.

(Update from pnkfelix: alex is above referring to the branch of work that I have saved at commit pnkfelix@10c46ebc8b42a188f6f565a7dc7253dbf1cdca90 ; which I may indeed still try to land if I cannot resolve my problems with his suggested revised patch to get rustdoc working within `check-stage1`; see below.)

---

The discussion log starts here: https://botbot.me/mozilla/rust-internals/msg/14337673/

Our conclusion was that both of the suggestions that @alexcrichton put in earlier comments on this PR (the little patches to prepend the target lib_path to the system dynamic library path env var) _do_ fix the problem locally.

_But_ ... they have their own issues (i.e. see nightmare scenarios discussed in the irc log), and so we do not want to adopt those patches.  Instead we will put in the more robust solution also discussed in the irc log, where the child process will set up its own `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` instead of having the parent muck with its own value for that env var before spawning the child process.

@pnkfelix, if you see this before this merges, would you be willing to include https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust/commit/d2914f88ed9d52b38692df029a029dfd9bc016e3 as part of this PR? It should allow enabling rustdoc at stage1.
@alexcrichton sure, I'll take your r+ off the commit temporarily and see what I can do with alexcrichton@d2914f8
@alexcrichton I'm going to force-push my adaptation of your patch here, but its not quite working yet; i'lll post the error after I do the force-push.

So atop commit 1dfb5b3, I get an error for `make check-stage1` during rustdoc's check of the regex crate.  It looks to me like its trying to resolve symbols for e.g. a reference from the target libregex crate to the `OwnedSlice::as_slice` method, but in doing so it is trying to resolve those symbols in the host's crate.

```
% make check-stage1 TESTNAME=Regex_1
cfg: build triple x86_64-apple-darwin
cfg: host triples x86_64-apple-darwin
cfg: target triples x86_64-apple-darwin
cfg: enabling more debugging (CFG_ENABLE_DEBUG)
cfg: host for x86_64-apple-darwin is x86_64
cfg: os for x86_64-apple-darwin is apple-darwin
cfg: using ccache clang
cfg: including test rules
run doc-crate-regex [x86_64-apple-darwin]

running 1 test
test re::Regex_1 ... FAILED

failures:

---- re::Regex_1 stdout ----
    <anon>:6:18: 6:44 error: dlopen(/Users/fklock/Dev/Mozilla/rust-fixstage1/objdir-check1-dbgopt/x86_64-apple-darwin/stage1/lib/rustlib/x86_64-apple-darwin/lib/libregex_macros-10a265ff-0.11-pre.dylib, 1): Symbol not found: __ZN11owned_slice19OwnedSlice$LT$T$GT$8as_slice10PTR_MARKER20h4ab916fef4e2db721Ba9v0.11.preE
      Referenced from: /Users/fklock/Dev/Mozilla/rust-fixstage1/objdir-check1-dbgopt/x86_64-apple-darwin/stage1/lib/rustlib/x86_64-apple-darwin/lib/libregex_macros-10a265ff-0.11-pre.dylib
      Expected in: /Users/fklock/Dev/Mozilla/rust-fixstage1/objdir-check1-dbgopt/x86_64-apple-darwin/stage1/lib/libsyntax-5de2fc8e-0.11-pre.dylib
     in /Users/fklock/Dev/Mozilla/rust-fixstage1/objdir-check1-dbgopt/x86_64-apple-darwin/stage1/lib/rustlib/x86_64-apple-darwin/lib/libregex_macros-10a265ff-0.11-pre.dylib
    <anon>:6 #[phase(syntax)] extern crate regex_macros;
                              ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    task 're::Regex_1' failed at '~Any', /Users/fklock/Dev/Mozilla/rust-fixstage1/src/libsyntax/diagnostic.rs:79


failures:
    re::Regex_1

test result: FAILED. 0 passed; 1 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured
```

I will try to look at this more tomorrow.  (Well, maybe.  Its Fête de la Victoire tomorrow, so we'll see.)

Anyway, thank you for your assistance on this so far alex, it has really gotten me over some hurdles.

@alexcrichton or wait, this is an instance of a case where we just aren't going to work, right?  I.e. this problem is probably because of `regex_macros`'s use of syntax extensions, and so _this_ should be disabled for `check-stage1` then, right?  (as opposed to my earlier strategy of turning off `rustdoc` across the board).
hmm let me see if rebasing atop a master with PR #13845 landed helps with anything here.
Yes, I would expect `make check-stage1-doc-crate-regex` to pass, and without #13845 I would expect it to fail when starting with a clean build directory.

@alexcrichton what do you think about the approach from commit 7a62e83 ? 

(I know your last comment said "I would expect `make check-stage1-doc-crate-regex` to pass", but as we discussed [on IRC](https://botbot.me/mozilla/rust-internals/msg/14360151/), the patch from PR #13845 explicitly excludes stage1 from the cases where `regex` gets a proper dependence upon `regex_macros` added.  So I think you should be okay with the spirit of this latest commit; I'm just wondering whether you also are okay with the methodology.)
r=me with a comment explaining why it's ignored

hmm, if I do:

```
% pwd
/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/src/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green
% /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/stage2/bin/rustc --out-dir /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green -L /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green lib.rs
% ln -nsf /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot-*.so /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so
% gcc -Wall -Werror -g -fPIC -m64 -L /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green main.c -o /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/main -lboot
/usr/bin/ld: warning: libgreen-f3eb09bc-0.11-pre.so, needed by /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/usr/bin/ld: warning: librustuv-30cdf6fe-0.11-pre.so, needed by /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/usr/bin/ld: warning: libstd-aad93cea-0.11-pre.so, needed by /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so: undefined reference to `io::stdio::println_args::h8c5752c79c70a99fhjq::v0.11.pre'
/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so: undefined reference to `start::h24799cd62201bf6aMyc::v0.11.pre'
/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so: undefined reference to `event_loop::he8e2d0b4e6bf62fey9f::v0.11.pre'
/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so: undefined reference to `rust_stack_exhausted'
/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so: undefined reference to `task::spawn::hb9c9406bc3ba0499Nbh::v0.11.pre'
```

then things fail just as they do in the log from the bors attempted run on Linux.

But if I do:

```
% /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/stage2/bin/rustc --out-dir /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green -L /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green lib.rs
% ln -nsf /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot-*.so /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/libboot.so
% LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/stage1/lib/rustlib/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/lib gcc -Wall -Werror -g -fPIC -m64 -L/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green main.c -o /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/main -lboot
% LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green /home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rust-stage1/objdir-dbgopt-check/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-make/bootstrap-from-c-with-green/main
hello
% 
```

(note the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` on the gcc invocation), then things work out.
Interesting. I would have expected rpaths to take care of this...

@alexcrichton I think the LD_LIBRARY_PATH may be set in the environment in the run-make tests (or at least on this PR's run-make tests)... didn't you say something earlier about that overriding the rpath setting?

Perhaps, requiring it on `gcc` itself seems... odd though. Perhaps the linker is reading it?

The LD_LIBRARY_PATH does take precedent over rpath, but the rpath should work in this case because the libboot.so hasn't moved relative to its dependent libraries.

@alexcrichton I wonder if its a linker flag order problem.

While trying to make an isolated test case in C to try to replicate this, I noted the following:

```
% make libfoo.so
gcc -c -Wall -Werror -fpic -o foo.o foo.c
gcc -shared -o libfoo.so foo.o
% make test-1
gcc -Wall -L/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rpath -o test-1 main.c -lfoo
% make test-2
gcc -Wall -L/home/pnkfelix/Dev/Mozilla/rpath -lfoo -o test-2 main.c
/tmp/ccg3Pya4.o: In function `main':
main.c:(.text+0xf): undefined reference to `foo'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [test-2] Error 1
% 
```

The linker will sometimes discard libraries if they don't satisfy any outstanding symbols, so in the second case I think that because `main.o` appears after `-lfoo` on the linker command line that `-lfoo` is discarded. I've never really quite pinned down why and when this happens, but it definitely apperas to be happening sometimes...

okay, I worked out what was happening (we need to feed an appropriate `-Wl,-rpath-link=...` option to the `$(CC)` invocation), and I think I have a reasonable way to incorporate what's needed into the other changes on this PR.

I still need to make sure fixing linux didn't break mac, but hopefully I'll have an updated PR available soon.
(d'oh needs a rebase)
